comment:
No Longer Own

Completed Box 1, then stopped playing

This is perhaps the worst game that I have ever played - considering how many hours my gaming group put into this. Cannot believe that we slogged our way through till the end. We all enjoyed Season 1 so much that we kept hoping for just a little bit more of the magic.

But Season Two never delivers. Just a mush mash of rules, a confusing storyline, and an entirely brutal ending that is nearly impossible to win.

This game was a frustrating disaster. And, for the record, we logged ten wins. But when we won, it was mostly not even fun. And when we lost, especially at the impossible end, it was like, “No kidding, we had zero chance.”

I cannot understand how people can score this above a two. I get that we all have different tastes, but didn’t think anyone liked eating a rotten fish. And this game is a rotting fish.

Our group absolutely LOVES Pandemic and enjoyed every moment of S1. It deserves all the praise that game gets. It is balance is razor sharp. Your actions matter, your characters are meaningful.

However, that is season 1.

Season 2 is honestly one of the poorest designed games I have ever played. From prolog to points at every stage we wished we were playing something else. It is unapologetically mean to the players and will never let you forget that you are supposed to lose (and a vast majority of you will lose).

Unlocking areas often punish you, the mechanics introduced that seem to help you can hurt you later. If you are too lucky or too quick in the early games you can get yourself into a situation towards the end that is nearly impossible to overcome. If you are too unlucky or too late in the early game you will paint yourself in just as punishing of a corner.

This is BEFORE you take into account that the entire game requires a running spreadsheet to calculate where and when the next unavoidable card that really hurts you will be.

At no point, none, did it feel like we were ahead of the curve. At no point were we able to develop a rhythm or get a sense of achievement. It was so bad that ultimately when the twist came, our table was like "yeah, that explains why we suck so bad".

But its not us, it is the developers. If you love pandemic, skip this - is isn't pandemic, its a card resource management game where deviating slightly from the optimal path will result in failure. If you love S1, go play that again - you will have more fun.

What ever you do - DO NOT PLAY WITH 4 CASUAL PLAYERS. If you still want to give it a try, then when you start, play the prolog 10 times. It will be the most fun you will have - and odds are you won't have any fun.
No solo and a legacy game. All games should be easily able to be reset.
I though they could make it better, I was wrong.
Destroying my game? Not an option. Terrible dev decision.

I just finished the campaign with my dad. I won't spoil the game out of respect, even though the game has shown no respect at all to its players.

The gist is: You have no sense of end goal/direction till OVER half-way in. The game punishes you for literally everything you do. And I mean basically everything. Once you do figure out what you were supposed to do you have no time to do it. I could go on and on. It's actually awful. Truely the worst game (Board & Video games included) I have ever played.

What you do need to know is, if you manage to put up with the game don't expect to win. Seriously. I don't think Matt and Rob could have designed a more forced-to-lose ending if they tried. I was actually pissed and yelling when I read how you are supposed to "win". Trust me, it's rigged. Hated the game all the way through, will never play it again.

Oh and story? Your leaders left and it's up to you to stop racism.

Disliked this game pretty much the whole way through. The story was bad, there was no direction throughout the game as to what you needed to do and the ending was just stupid and completely anticlimactic. I tried to give it a chance but our whole group hated it by the end and it was a slog to even get it to the table at the end.
Fuera del top 100.

Jokingly predicted the surprise twist a few months in. The story was so uninteresting I couldn't even remember it between games (even games on the same day). Terrible. Turned me off on legacy games and nearly erased my love for the Pandemic series as a whole.
I hate this game as much as I love s1.
liked this even less than the last legacy game
Great follow up to season one looking forward to season 3
This game is way too hard for my taste. Punishing.
2-4 Spieler

Not a game.
It's a puzzle.. which you are expected to do over and over..

yes, big twist on the "Pandemic" game core
but legacy, story-driven and not that good
nothing what I would want

As if the original wasn't bad enough, they made another? sheesh.
Someone needs to stop wringing this cash cow and come up with an innovative game.

This game did not resonate with us AT ALL. We played 22 times because we did so poorly. We felt misguided, and it felt so different from other pandemics that we felt like we were constantly doing it wrong. We played this over the course of 12 months almost to the day, occasionally getting 2 plays in a session. It was just rough. The story was not engaging.

For the record pandemic is not one of my favorite games, but I loved Season 1. My group (same group we played season 1 with) also loved Season 1 and did not enjoy Season 2 at all.

Just lost March 4x in a row between the two games I'm running -- lost 2x last night and 1st try in April, 2x today with Faye, even knowing what needed to be done all too well. I HATE games in which you have lost due to the opening shuffle of the cards but don't know it until you've played it out, your actions cannot possibly do more than delay the defeat, and that is what happens in this game in this month. It's rating and ranking have just taken a MAJOR dive.

EDIT: Just lost May 2x, again due to the opening shuffle, defeated on the 4th turn due to 8 Incidents with no way to stop them. FINALLY were able to get to Lost Haven & get more cubes -- too late. Were never able to draw enough cards to Recon Europe, either. Rating now down to a 3. I'd lower it to a 2, but I'm not going to quit on Faye.

EDIT: Just got slaughtered in both tries of December. The game IS broken. Utterly impossible to win without massive cheating or an unbelievable string of good luck. I don't think you'd have better than a 1/10 chance of winning even if you KNEW everything you needed to know at the beginning of the campaign. Words cannot describe my outrage and feeling of being ripped off.
This game is a textbook example of throwing in mechanisms that, as delightful and innovative as they may be, simply do not work well together -- in this case, because you do not have TIME to do what you need to do. And WORST OF ALL: you are often screwed from the opening shuffle of the cards, but you will not know it until you've wasted your time trying to overcome the impossible.
The last condition of forcing the carrier to ALSO have the necessary collection of cards to make way to Johannesburg is unfathomably stupid in concept -- unless you're trying to ensure a loss.
Will not likely trust this designer any time soon.
FINAL RATING = ZERO!
We will enjoy the game burning party...
Has to be the dumbest thing I have ever played!

Very expensive game, but cheap shabby plastic material. The innovation is, compared to Season 1 and standard Pandemic, you take away cubes rather than putting cubes on the board. We played until May and then gave up totally frustrated. You can´t win this game without having a lot of luck. Afterwards, I read, you need to scratch free a certain card to have a chance to make it. Well, we scratched free a lot of cards, but eventually not this one. Unplayable game!
If you want to play a good cooperative game, try out Robinson Crusoe, The Dwarves, Magic Maze, Talisman Legendary Tales or Gloomhaven!

By far the worst board game I have ever played, which is surprising because our gaming group found Season 1 to be the best board game they have ever played.

The difficulty on this game is so ridiculous it is impossible to even begin to get going before you lose. More often than not, the game was over before we got around the table two times, meaning after all the time spent in set up and strategy talk, some players got 1 turn before the game ended.

Avoid at all costs, play season 1 instead!

First of all, Pandemic was always one of my favourite games. Until I played first legacy season. Continuous changing of rules, hundreds of new rules and almost no consistency made me dislike the game. It became torture.
Second season managed to top this by defying every possible logic. It actively demoralizes players and managed to make me dislike Pandemic altohether. HThanks guys, for ruining it all!
Addition after August, II season: I seriously suspect the authors of this game designed it to deliberately make you hate Pandemic! WHY????
Legacy games are an affront to God.
Legacy...Yak..Boardgames should NOT be disposable...
The original cards and the ones at the boxes have different background color....
Same issues as season 1.
A crass commercialism game that is designed to be destroyed as it is played will always merit a 1 from me.
Legacy==1 .Also, balance for obvious reasons.
Awfull production quality (Dutch version), crappy transaltion, scratch surface that you can't scratch without damaging the card.... boring/repetitive gameplay...
Didn't survive the fire ritual ?
Started off fun but about halfway through the game, the rules and extra crap you have to keep up with turn it into a terrible experience.

Complete flop for us. Didn't make it through. Large rules overhead. We must have missed a few rules that made a very significant impact in our games and by half way through we just stopped as it didn't make sense to continue. Season 1 and season 0 were awesome and some of my top gaming experiences with the same group - unfortunate that this one didn't sit well with us.

This game was a christmas present. I have never played Pandemic or Pandemic Legacy Season 1, so this is a rating purely based on this game.

We played the game with 2 players. To us, it seemed far too easy. We lost 3 times in total, all other games we won. Maybe we missed something in the rules or we just had a good combination of characters and the right ideas at the right moments, I don't know. After we found our strategy, it felt quite repetitive - every game was basically the same all over again with a few different objectives. Therefore, it took us quite a while to finish all months and the last one we only played to be done with the game.

The quality of the components is nice, but so many things get destroyed and in the end, you can basically through out the game. That seems like a total waste. I wonder, if you couldn't have the same experience of a legacy game with resettable components. Then you could pass on the game to someone else after you had finished.

This was very disappointing and I am not interested in playing it again.

As of 11/11/17 we've played nine total games.
Prologue: 2 plays, both wins
January: Win
February: Win
March: Win
April: Loss/Loss
May: Loss/Loss

Getting the feeling that there's no choices that actually affect the story (also realizing that that was true with Season 1). The most important things and major mechanics will get revealed whether you win or lose. The game has been very punishing with a bland, forgettable story so far. The fact that you can get a plague cube DURING SET UP is one of the worst mechanisms I've ever seen in a game. I do want a challenge but I also don't think getting demoralized right off the bat is fun in the slightest. Makes me not want to even waste my time. We crushed the first season in four days, season 2 is going to get shelved after these nine plays and we'll see if we ever finish it. Not sure that Legacy games are for me after all.

After only 2 plays, I have to rate this much lower than Season 1. Makes less sense, is less fun, and the component quality (specifically the stickers) is absolute garbage. Barely sticking actions, the *incredibly tiny January spoiler* 'Mandatory Objective' sticker not lining up with the creases on the board even if you line it up with the Latitude and Longitude lines. Don't get me wrong, we'll still 100% finish it, but we are NOT impressed.

Update after 4 plays: components are actually worse than I originally thought, and the massive increase to difficulty is majorly taking away from the fun of the game. I'm no longer sure we'll even bother to finish.

Update after 3 more plays: I actually can't believe the way this game piles difficulty on top of difficulty. We've lost more games so far by April than we lost in the entire playthrough of Season 1. We're going to make a few changes to the game to see if it even becomes possible. The action economy is completely untenable.
The RNG in this season is just lame. Multiple losses just because of unlucky draw making it impossible
My group found it punishingly difficult. So much so, that it just wasn't fun. It's a shame because we enjoyed season 1.

Let's be honest here, this game has great ideas but suffers from one major flaw - it is WAY too hard. We played through S1 and were able to keep our funding level at 2-4, a fun win/loss ratio. In this game we have played 3 months and lost 5/6 games. This is not fun, and the game introduces way too much to screw you over and you can't recover. I'm not having fun, my group is not having fun, we are done. What a disappointment.

Played to June, but whole group generally found it a slog and not enjoyable, losing most months twice to what seemed like punishing mechanics. We found it very difficult to complete recon objectives and keep the board state healthy at the same time. A big disappointment after enjoying season 1 so much.
Won’t play ever again.

Up to April... This game is MEAN! It is really really hard, unless you get some lucky draws from the both decks. But, the story is starting to evolve, so it's very interesting. We'll see.....

We give up. It's not fun to just keep getting beat up like this. I don't understand how anyone enjoyed this game, unless they just had substantially better luck with it.
I thought this was a dramatic step down from Season I (and I was disappointed with it). Even with a great group to play with this game stunk.

This game is hot garbage. Long setup, tedious play and a statistically negligible chance for any outcome besides total failure. Two stars for the satisfaction of throwing this piece of shit in the trash when it was over.

Couldn't hate this game more. What a let down after season 1. So ambiguous about goals and brutal when not making those goals that we just kept failing and could never break the cycle. No fun at all, ended up destroying it for parts after 5 games.
The first legacy game that my group has ever played that we decided not to finish. The mechanics are totally broken for 4 players, and the beats of the story did nothing to help. Just bad.

So - I wasn't overly enthused with Season 1, but I figured I'd still give Season 2 a shot. This was rough. I rage quit after the early September month back in 2018 and could only bring myself to finishing it now in 2021. Basically, everything I love about Pandemic makes the legacy version of it a complete pain to play for me. The rules were overly convoluted, the manual became less usable over time, mistakes or bad luck magnified into making subsequent games tougher, etc. In the end, we actually did fairly well - won with 740 pts - but I feel it was more luck than anything else. We could have just as easily lost the last game. It was unsatisfying and I really wish I wasn't a completionist and had just tossed this in the trash a long time ago.

Made me hate Pandemic (and I loved season 1!). Too many stickers. Too many rules to remember. Too difficult. Misery simulator that gets harder and harder. TOO MANY STICKERS. The game-end upgrades and the rationed events don't feel powerful enough to compensate. Core theme and mechanics not different enough from season 1 to be interesting. My win rate was 25%. Avoid.

What a disappointment this game was for me. The normal pandemic I like and understand the objective. Having played through September and lost most games except January and February I was done with it. Constant changing and adding rules makes it difficult for me to understand what my main objective is and those may not be the goals for that month. This was my first legacy game and while I like the concept, I now know legacy games are not for me.

Such a letdown after season 1. March and april were just afwul. We won all other months first try until october (!) but it just wasn't fun at all. The balance seemed totally off. Way too many actions, winning only just, not leaving room for exploration, so so many annoyances... So we stopped and skipped november and december. We were eager to buy and play season 0, but not anymore. Plenty of other fun games around...

Aesthetics - 1/2
Mechanics - 0/2
Involvement - 1/2
Game length - 0/2
Other - 0/2 (clearly a failure of a legacy game)

Not nearly as good as season 1. More difficult that it needed to be and it could not keep my groups interest. I dropped the box when I was taking it out of my car and the box split causing all the components, including the legacy deck,to fall all over the garage floor.

I decided it wasn't worth the effort to put the legacy deck back together so I picked it all up and threw it in the trash.

I will have to think hard before trying season 3 if it is released.

I love Pandemic. I disliked the Legacy idea. I hate destroying board games. So I kept away from this series. I finally tried Season 1 on the Tabletop Simulator. We liked it. So I chanced acquiring this since I got some credit at a game store.

We tried a couple of the prologue games before diving into the campaign. I thought the prologue game was dull. I wouldn't play it if it weren't for the campaign. I would rate the prologue game a 4 (whereas Pandemic is a solid 9).

Somewhere around the middle of the year, we started losing and everything looked bleaker and bleaker. It was taking a long time to set up and we would often lose in 3 turns (10 minutes). Often we had 3 incidents before anybody had a turn. Everybody was discouraged and wanted to give up. It wasn't fun.

We persevered until September. We then noticed that I placed a sticker in the wrong place (100E instead of 100W). This totally screwed up the campaign.

It is perhaps wrong to have the rating so low for a mistake on my part. But that is what the Legacy idea is selling. You play it once and you destroy things. The experience is the whole thing. Our experience was horrible and thus the rating. Mistakes happen in games. Sometimes it takes several plays to get the rules right in a complex game. Pandemic Legacy is complicated and it is compounded by having an evolving ruleset. An awful experience caused by a mistake is totally valid and should be counted.
Basically unwinnable if the randomness is against you. After a fantastic time with season 1, we were expecting more, but came away disappointed after 6 losses in a row. No desire to play again.
Initially I was positive to the game, but the inability to win the game because we did to good is rediculously bad.
finite fun via legacy litter
The game is broken and prevents you from finding the map based on the bottleneck that is Black cards.
Low fun/hour. Completed the game, but never an enjoyable session.

Theme is basically Pandemic, which I like, but more expensive and more marketing and totally not sustainable; it' s too exclusive, which means it shuts out other players after the first time; and after 12 games you throw it away. Not my kind of game, I refuse to buy or play it.
We were glad it's over

My group enjoyed Season 1, and appreciates Pandemic games in general, but Season 2 has serious problems.

Compared to season 1, season 2 is more complex with no corresponding benefit; the rules are harder to track as the game progresses, and the goal is constantly obfuscated making it difficult to discern a coherent strategy. We completed the game but did not enjoy season 2 in the end. Overall it was a very disappointing experience, and not worth the price in time or money.

Annoying + will never play again = 2 (rating by definition)
Pandemic is great, reverse Pandemic is the opposite of course. Not only they flunked and buried the main mechanic, there's barely anything happening and the last month plays itself.
Loved S1, hated this. Became unplayable (as opposed to unwinnable) towards the end if you made the wrong choices earlier.

Certainly the weakest if the trilogy and I think this is full of unintuitive rules, fiddly steps, and much more work than fun. At one point you need to count the number of cards in the deck during the setup step which is just mind bogglingly unfun.

Update: after 7 plays I really dislike this game and dread playing it. Each game gets longer and longer (and so does set up accordingly). We never remembered the rules and always had to refresh them.

Season 1 is INCREDIBLE.

This just strays too far and crumbles under it's own weight.

We loved season 1. It is one of my best gaming experiences ever. However, this season is not fun. We are not bad gamers, but this is just loss after loss (often times half way to losing just on setup). I am sure there is some efficiency to playing we are missing, but not that much.

How this got through playtesting with this type of experience is baffling. If it is part of the narrative they are trying to push, they could inform via story. If it is just bad luck and bad play, that's another thing, but we are struggling bringing this to the table any longer. I have only so much gaming time in my life, and right now I don't want this game to be part of it.
Soooo done with this game, still two months to go. Kill me now.

One of the most disappointing games I have ever played. For reference we have played over 200 games of Pandemic (all versions combined). Season 1 is a 10, full stop. Why do I hate this one? It feels broken. The difficulty curve is weird where it starts on the hard side, then, without any spoilers, it got way too easy for us mid game when it should have been ramping up. We played twice, and are certain we weren't playing wrong. For us it just feels nothing like Seasons 1 or 0.

Game was broken for us, after Month 4 we felt like we didn't had any chance to win. We lost a lot and we even didn't finished this game, because we didn't had fun at all.
We played a lot of Base Pandemic and Season 1. We still love Pandemic but I cant recommend Season 2.
Couldn’t even finish it. What a bland story paired with impossible game play (at 2 player). Terrible.
Started out well, but we just never got a rhythm with it.
Hated it, especially the radical rule change at the end - made it feel like the entire game was a waste of my time.

I know that this heavily relies on having the right playgroup to do these kinds of games but I haven't found that yet. I've tried to play this campaign twice with different playgroups (collectively 11 games) but we've always stopped the campaign and can't get any further in the story.

The gameplay is fun but if you keep losing it felt like we'd get nowhere in the story. We only got to March after 4 games. April took 2 more games. Since we would only play it once every 2-4 weeks we were always having to relearn the rules (or checking for new rules we forgot) it would take us too long to play. Our best guess was 1.5 more years and we didn't want to keep that experience for so long.

This was not for my playgrounds. That is for certain. The bare minimum of 12 games assuming that you won every single time is a bit too much for us.

So my recommendation is that if you think your playgroup can put in the time go for it. It definitely can be very enjoyable and rewarding.

The worst thing I have ever played. I don't know how you screw up Pandemic Legacy but they did. Most boring gameplay imaginable and impossibly hard. The setting is also really weird and no one gives a s**t about what happens in the story.
Lo peor

Cooperative
Owned by Jeffrey Tam & Howie Chan

Snowball problem. People often point to the need to "catch the clues," but my group found those trivial to discover. The problem is that if you get unlucky trying to unearth something (even if you've already figured out you need to do it), you can get into a snowball situation that screws the rest of the play. The campaign was depressing and oppressive. It took a couple years to finish because no one wanted to slog through the rest of it.

Took what made season one interesting and developed a convoluted mess. Enjoyed the game, but it all felt too heavy handed and over the top. Rules were nonsensical in spots and “rules for the sake of rules” rather than thematically tied.

No. See Pandemic 1

Legacy. Co-op
Really slow...6 months before changing goals, that is 6 months out of 12 doing the same game

I was truly looking forward to this game after playing Season one. Then after playing a few games I truly wanted to throw it away without even finishing it. Sadly this game is nothing like Season one. This game is tedious and punishing on the players. Losing 14 games in a row is not fun. Only to have the game punish you more for it. I only rated this a 3 because I know some effort went into making it.. This was a poor showing and will make me think before buying another Pandemic game.
Season 1 was a good game with a cool gimmick. Season 2 is the same gimmick, but without the actual game. Pass

Our group finally finished Pandemic Legacy: Season 2. After loving Season 1, Season 2 was quite a let down. I don't know if it's just that Season 1 was great and this was so-so, or if it's also a function of now having played multiple other legacy games that were only so-so (or worse - looking at you, Seafall), that I'm kind of over legacy games in general. Fun for a bit - but not a great game by any stretch of the imagination. Play Season 1 for sure, but there are lots of better games to play than Season 2.

(12/30/2017) - Received as a gift from Brad and Dana!

(02/15/2020) - [3] - Other than some initial excitement over the new "keep supplies on the board" gameplay instead of the usual "remove cubes desperately" mechanic that Pandemic is known for, this one really fell flat for us.

Painfully stale objectives that hardly ever changed. Anyone could have seen the "Utopia is bad" part of the story coming from a mile away. The other twist landed with a thud, due to us being largely sour on the game quite some time before the big reveal.

The need to not retcon Season 1 was handled with a large gap in time between the events of Season 1 and Season 2. While I see the reason for doing this, it also felt like playing two unconnected games. I never felt like I was dealing with the aftermath of CODA from Season 1. It just felt like a completely different story that happened to mention CODA from time to time.

Maybe this is finally Pandemic fatigue setting in for me, but I think I'm done with this series, barring a complete overhaul and redesign.

Overall I found this game fell flat of its predecessor in a few ways.
The base gameplay of this game differs from classic Pandemic - and ultimately I feel this led to its downfall. Different by itself would not have been a problem, but the base gameplay of season two just isn't good.
*spoilers ahead*
Two much of this game was spent on trying to put out fires while doing the same "create 3 new supply stations". That was the point of most months, create new supply stations - a mind numbing task to be building to for most of the game. Then many of the cool abilites that you could buy in season one were hidden behind searches, which relied heavily on randomness to come up in the deck.The game felt as if it took more away instead of adding more to it. A good example of what they could have done to elevate pandemic would be spirit island. Instead we ended up with a hollow version of a game. They focused on Legacy first and game second, and season 2 suffers greatly for it.

Ended up with the second best ending, but I was just glad to be over with it. I'll not be buying season 3 at launch, if ever.

My gaming group had a blast playing Season 1, and then we started playing Season 2. We hated it. The games were all monotonous and we just lost over and over again to a crushing lack of supply cubes. I'm still scratching my head as to how the initial few months of the game are either fun or winnable. We persisted through April before calling it quits. It's not inherently a bad game (I'm guessing), but from what I can tell from the forums, you have to make certain things happen to the landscape of the board before any big breakthroughs occur, which I think we just didn't achieve. How could we when there were already 5+ exposed cities after not even a few turns and no way to manage our resources to protect them? Losing on repeat with no end in sight and no means to improve one's lot for months on end? I'll go play something else.

After playing season 1 and loving every intense moment, we went into season 2 excited! But now just finishing June, we've lost the game more times than we can count and most of the time we felt like there was nothing we could've done better. And sadly, the story isn't as gripping to me as I'm not invested in what's going on (probably because we keep losing). Maybe they were going for the hopelessness of a post-apocalyptic world but it's so hopeless than my group is struggling to keep invested. We just want to power through the game to say that we finished it.

So disappointed with Season 2 after absolutely loving Season 1. We can't even muster up the will to finish the game. One of the things I liked about Season 1 is that it balanced out well -- the game had adjustments that made it harder or easier based upon how well you're doing. Season 2 doesn't have this -- we lost a game in the second round because of how our board is structured. We're halfway through and haven't had any big surprises when it comes to stories, windows or packages. I doubt we'll ever finish out the season.

(I love regular Pandemic and Season 1)

I didn’t like it. It removed or changed my favorite parts of the formula. It took willpower to complete the campaign.
Quizá sea por las expectativas creadas después del Season 1, pero este juego no nos gustó nada y dejamos la campaña a medias
Not sure why, but this game does not feel at all like the predecessor. Boring.
Was fun to play, but gets repetitive very fast. Last game is impossible to win, that will be frustrating for a lot of people. Overall, Season 1 had the better story and more immersive gameplay.

Didn't get on with this and did not finish. Subverting the core mechanic by placing cubes that the game removes did not work in my opinion.

Placing areas on the map via sticker despite having a narrative purpose felt like a gimmick.

Never got captured by the story.

This had nothing on Pandemic Season One
This fell flat for me. Love the creativity, but it didn’t resonate.

Akin to giving students an impossible test as a psychological experiment, not to see if they can pass the test, but to see how well they handle the stress of failing the test. (See also, Kobayashi Maru)

The Final Reckoning
Delivered: 371 (Near Collapse)

Complexity √ - Each time I play this game, I become more disappointed after the masterpiece that was Season One. There are too many ways for your plans to come undone with no way to mitigate this. If you do win, it seems to be more by luck than design. We are grinding through it at the moment, but it is a grind, and we are only continuing (I suspect) because we have started it....

Edit 29/01/21
I couldn't see us finishing this. Probably because I don't like the way things have turned out. Everything appears to have gone wrong right from the first month in terms of our card draws, and there has been no way back. We have lost more than we have won. I have moved this on (= binned it)
Trash

A slog. Halfway through, I just started dreading playing the next session. Maybe the back half becomes stronger, but I couldn't bring myself to push through when there's so many other great games to play.

I was very disapointed with this second season.
I found that the mecanics were very punishing and directed to conter what the players may have built in the previous months
This was not nearly as fun as the others (which were my favorite games). I couldn't even finish this one.
Nada que ver con la magistral primera temporada. Sensación total de ir a ciegas durante gran parte de la campaña a merced del azar. Muy aburrido. No la terminamos.

Only played half through the campaign. Not as lean and elegant as season 1 and the base game. Too much of everything (possible actions, rules etc.) so that playing becomes exhausting even though I have played pandemic for years.
Rating 4 = To someone with a simliar taste like me: Play this game if you don't have anything else to do.
Not nearly as good as Season 1. Some weak design decisions made it all but impossible to win…
Game is too swingy in the campaign - finding an event early allowed us to swing through several missions far too easily

It's fun, but I believe the game is trying to be something it's not. It's similar enough to Pandemic and the story is a logical continuation of season 1. But, it's just not as fun as season 1. Perhaps season 0 will be better.

Co-op, legacy. After the first few rounds we've been really enjoying the implementation of Pandemic and the subtle improvements to the legacy system likely learned from the first season.

Well... the bottom dropped out on this one (now @ November). We now realize that we missed a couple small, subtle rules and clues starting in the early months that caused us to fall behind, not develop an effective strategy, and be forced to reveal stickers/packages month after month b/c we couldn't achieve the objectives in time. Once we realized our problem (triggered by a new card we were forced to reveal that had a rule interaction that seemed incompatible with how we were playing) we realized there was no way we could Retcon the game back to its state in Apr/May.
It's so sad that one of our best gaming experiences (from Season 1 we had such optimistic hopes about this one) has been pretty bitterly ruined for us as we slogged month after month to do just enough to not have the world collapse but not be able to gain enough momentum to make any real progress. Its been a slog to get this far and I won't be surprised if we don't finish since we're likely facing several losses just to get enough cities connected; maybe we can get a win at the end of the last month. I appreciate some of the twists to the typical Pandemic formula that were introduced, and maybe it's all on us, but a couple key rules and wrinkles were missed by us and there was no recovering after that.

Finally finished this one, but had to force ourselves to do it. While we scored really well, we found this one was not as engaging as Season One was and play felt like a chore. We were glad to be done with it. Story was pretty predictable.

That we had to draw the exact cards that was needed in order to win several of the months, was just too much. Beside that, some months were fun. Some months we could discover stuff, but most months we could not.
Well, I liked some of the months, but ultimately we felt it was impossibly hard and unfair. We didn't even play December.

So, this is Season 2 of Pandemic. Definitely a similar vibe, but the world is super tiny to start off with. The game has only 1 color of cubes to put out (Supplies) which makes setup and tear down a breeze and even just the general gameplay. I'm quite a fan of how this was handled. Plague cubes are placed when a city runs out of supply cubes and you draw that card again. They are unable to be removed and become a problem quickly as you can't begin your turn there or you'll take exposure, which may lead to your death. You can still place supplies in that city, but you want to get in and get out.

I've found this version harder than Season 1 by far, but still not that difficult. Granted, I don't expect legacy games to be mind crushingly difficult as you don't want the game to be super difficult as you only have a limited number of times to play it. I'm also unsure on how to rate this game. I suppose when it comes down to it, it'll be rated as the experience I've had with it. I haven't seen any surprises yet, but I expect a few twists later on in the year.

Taking a break from this in the 2nd half of May after losing 4 games in a row. Will come back over winter break.

+ Uncovering the world throughout a campaign is a fun mechanic.
+ Strategically creating routes is similarly interesting as well, although it's pretty obvious where those routes ought to go.
+ It's Pandemic - it's a fun enough game.
- Soul-crushingly difficult, and I say this having nearly-aced Season 1 and Season 0 before this. We've lost 4 games in a row even while having cheated a little to give ourselves an edge due to this difficulty, and our victories have been very hard-won. If you find yourself low on supplies you can be *permanently* screwed over before you even take your first turn, and that's the polar opposite of fun in an already punishing game. God help you if you forsake a city that has a card you haven't scratched off yet, much less one that HAS A LOST HAVEN WITH PERMANENT EXTRA SUPPLIES ATTACHED TO IT. Thank god we found that, but even with those supplies and a new key sea route the game is still kicking us to the curb.
/ The silver-lining to losing is that at least we've been making progress each game.
- On paper, the game wants you to connect new cities to the grid, but in practice this comes with a very real cost for future games where you'll be punished by drawing isolated cities from the infection deck, which are extremely hard to manage. Your reward - extra player cards with scratch-off bits, and *maybe* an extra production unit if you can somehow keep all those cities from falling - is not enough to make up for this. The game is at odds with itself as far as this mechanic is concerned.
- Setup time is the longest of the three Pandemic Legacy games, and in the middle of the usually boring setup process that one person can do, you need to make the VERY IMPORTANT strategic judgement call of disbursing supplies - something other people may want to chime in on - before going back to recounting the number of cities you have in your player deck, which is not the same number as the number of cities on the grid, which is not the same number as the number of cities on the grid that count towards production units.
- Perhaps it's just our luck but we've been hit with the classic "draw an epidemic, get the bottom card, shuffle, then draw the card you just got from the bottom and immediately get punished permanently with no recourse" Pandemic Legacy problem a LOT in this campaign. It's still as frustrating as ever.
- Maybe it's just my old copy, but the stickers are unsticky and are curling up from the board. Also the scratch-off "stuff" is the most annoying crap to dispose of and gets everywhere and *stains itself into wood tables* if you're not extremely careful.

I still want to finish it but the game is making itself very difficult to like through its many glaring flaws.

EDIT: Gave it away not even half-finished. Can't recommend over the other two seasons or other great Legacy games like Clank!
Not as engaging as Season 1 and way too difficult for most players. Every victory felt like luck and not like good planning and player choices.

After playing pandemic legacy season 1 and absolutely loving it, I was very excited to play season 2. After playing the entire S2 campaign, I really liked the exploration focus; a nice change of pace using stickers to uncover new parts of the game However, that's where things fall apart drastically.

First, the quality of the stickers are awful. They peel, don't stick to the cardboard and player cards and, if you're OCD, you'll be annoyed the entire way through the campaign until you use tape. All annoyances with scratching (and in many ways ruining) the cards is maintained from S1. But what really disappointed was the clearly unbalanced, swingy, and seemingly guaranteed losses in a few specific months. Additionally, unlike S1, the game was far too linear on character development. For example, we barely ever changed characters until all of a sudden without notice you're screwed due to luck of the draw from the massive card deck.

All in all, this game is a far cry from S1, so buyer beware. If you're completionist this game will be a slog but after it's done you'll feel fulfilled you made in through to the end, win or lose. That said, this game is great value for money: 16 plays and 20+ hours later was still worth it. I just can't rate this higher because the gameplay was mediocre at best.

“Well slim-slam there, racker! Cop a squat an’ I’ll skivvy you a tell of some sick bashers who went all AWOL up on the cargo catch...”

So begins the pilot of Sick Patrol: 2089, an “edgy” 2002 reboot of the cult favorite Sick Patrol, an unintentionally comedic medical drama from the late 1980s.

Much of it was shot on leftover Waterworld (1995) sets that had been cut loose after principle photography and drifted to the center of the Great Pacific Gyre, where they were subsequently populated by a contingent of rogue Pinoy merchant marines and their Brazilian "girlfriends". This population was used as enthusiastic extras for the duration of the show, leading to online outrage as the main cast was, without variation, made up of snow-white Europeans and Americans. While problematic from a racially tone-deaf angle, it actually enhanced the (again, unintentional) comedic milieu.

Of course, the aggressively hip "future-speak"—sounding like a cartoon character from a 1990s snack commerical—didn't help.

I found season 1 to be much better. Put it this way, my group played through season 1 and worked through season 2.

We completed season 1 in about a calendar year. It took us about 4 years to complete season 2. Part of the slowdown was the real-life pandemic. Another part of it was this game simply wasn't as compelling as the first one. The storyline was less intriguing, and the reversal need to add cubes wasn't as fun.

From a design perspective, the "strategize as part of setup" aspect was kind of interesting. As a player, though, I hated that aspect. If it'd been a while since you last played and needed a refresher on how to play, that mechanic is merciless. Setup on its own could take an hour. Even if you'd played recently, the need to strategize to get the game set up made it feel like work. Decision fatigue was a big factor in this game, even compared to season 1.

The aspect of season 2 I most enjoyed was the recon. Unveiling larger parts of the map was cool.

Very disappointing compared to Season 1. The idea of being able to control which parts of the map you want to explore was interesting, but because the game can't know where people are going to go, there was a lot of redundancies built in to the game, and a lot of cards meant to "catch you up" if you're not progressing fast enough. I appreciate that they tried something new, but it didn't pay off. I did, however, like the mechanic of pick up and deliver more than the traditional pandemic mechanic.

The Pandemic Legacy games are still the best legacy games there are. It's amazing they came out so early and nailed it. I love regular Pandemic and the legacy version is even better. Even though Pandemic has the risk that a bad starting shuffle could wreck a game. Its strength is that you need to be clever to do well, and switch up your strategies as the game changes, which it does in big ways despite always following the basics of Pandemic. Your decisions feel incredibly meaningful. The fact that it is fully cooperative really helps. A lot of legacy games that aren't fully cooperative have to make changes that aren't so meaningful to avoid throwing off the balance of the game, or they do throw off the balance of the game and aren't fun to play as a campaign. Without giving much away, as you play Pandemic Legacy, you will get lots of new cards, goals, rules stickers, characters, and other game components. There are 12 missions, and you get 2 chances to beat each. There is a deck of cards you progress through with each mission, win or lose. There are dossiers panels to open containing stickers. You will be putting stickers all over the rules, board, and cards, forever changing them. There are boxes to open during certain triggers, giving you bigger components. And after each game, win or lose, you can make choices to upgrade different things, making your team stronger. The game will tell you to destroy components, but I just saved "destroyed" components in a separate bag as mementos. This game is a one time play through, but the game is so good that it is still worth it even though it's pricey. That said, if you don't like puzzles or don't quickly adjust to change, this game is probably not for you. If you do well, the rewards will compound. If you do poorly, you get some help, but probably not enough to make the game fun for you. And if characters die, you might get a lot weaker. Also, the game is cooperative and you will need to make decisions as a group. For me, the game is fantastic, one of the best ever, but I can see how playing it with the wrong group could ruin it. Because the game is so unique and uses stickers, it's very important to read things carefully, and you will need to look up some rules clarifications online or just make judgement calls as a group. If you make a mistake, it can be impossible to reset from it. These are not reusable stickers, and they don't peel off. But you can punish or aid yourself to make up for mistakes, but agreeing on what is a fair correction is a challenge. We did screw up one big thing and caught it after a game, and then punished ourselves even harder for it. Just make sure multiple players are reading the rules and keeping an eye out for mistakes. Double and triple checking before placing stickers. The game quality is great, but it can be difficult to write on the character sheets. Some pens work better on them than others. It can be tricky to peel the stickers from their backings too, and lay them down straight. It's not for the obsessive compulsive. So far, I have played season 1 and 2. Season 1 is my favorite. The theme & gameplay is great in both. Though the artwork is better in season 2, especially the character art which is more customizable, in a post apocalyptic theme where you start on floating cities in the ocean and must discover the map as the season goes. Season 1 has the traditional Pandemic look, with the full map revealed from the start. But I felt like season 1 ended really well, taking into account your overall progress to give you a final score that was more meaningful, while season 2 pinned all your success on a final gauntlet. Season 2 had more randomness because you had to make decisions without knowing what was hidden in the map. We put off going to some places thinking we were doing ourselves a favor, but instead ended up hurting ourselves considerably. But both are great games and you could start with either. Note that season 1 and 2 come in 2 box colors each. There is no difference to the gameplay in the 2 colors. It is basically so you can play 2 campaigns simultaneously and tell them apart.

 POSITIVE POINTS:

++ Pandemic is a great cooperative game, so a better version with a legacy story-driven campaign to it is an awesome gaming experience (this is how we must approach this game, as a gaming experience and not just a game, so the non-replayability after the campaign is more acceptable this way).
++ I really like that they did something completely different than just another Pandemic Legacy Season 1, with a new basic mechanism.
++ The evolving story of the legacy campaign, which leads to evolving game rules, increase the fun to solve the ever-evolving puzzle of this game (and really needs players to change strategy sometimes).


 NEGATIVE POINTS:

-- I hate buying a game that have a finite shelf life. You can play one full campaign of 12 to 24 games and then you're done with this game (you can no longer play it with the full Legacy experience).
-- On the point above, I would have like that the designers would include a sealed envelope that would have official variants to play the game using your own unique board afterward (to mitigate the one time use aspect).
-- This is a lower value game (strictly speaking, because of the lack of replayability of the Legacy campaign), but still a great value gaming experience.
-- (Not a concern for me, but an important recommandation) This game should always be played with the same people and individual games should be played relatively close together (ideally at least a game every week, max every two weeks) to keep the additional rules fresh in your memory.
-- This game has a strong memory aspect to it (since there are multiple copies of each city cards in the Propagation deck), so I suggest to new players to keep a log of the cities in the Propagation deck, in order to help plan the strategy instead of trying to remember what's in there (as planning is fun, but forcing to remember something you know you should remember but doesn't, isn't).
-- Like many legacy games, the play time is longer than written on the box, especially on certain months.

I have to say, I am REALLY loving this one! I went in pretty apprehensive because we just finished Season 1 and it left me a little "meh". So, I am only 4 games into this one thus far and will continually update this (and the score) as I progress and have new thoughts about it, but as it stands right now, it's a 10.

The things I am loving: Absolutely love the board design and artwork. It's really giving me a "Fallout" feel with the colors and how the board looks like some kinda metal map thing with the rust around the edges. The gameplay, although similar, is a fun little twist on the original Pandemic formula where you are trying to ADD cubes (supplies) to cities instead of remove them. But at the same time there are these Plague cubes that can pop up and spread which cannot be removed.

The legacy aspects are more fun than season 1 as well. Now you have cards that can be scratched to find stuff with the new "Search" action. The board itself is discovered over the course of play with new stickers being placed on the board to fill out the land as you discover it. It's a really neat system that I think does it better than Clank Legacy (which is newer).

Between the post-apocalyptic theme (which I will admit I am extremely biased towards), the artwork, the board design, the new legacy elements and the interesting gameplay, this is a MASSIVE improvement on season 1. And to be honest, this is a contender (so far) for beating out my current favorite legacy game, Betrayal Legacy.

Update:

We just finished with April and our next game will be the start of May. We lost both games in April, the first one was due to some extremely bad luck card draws and we couldn't control the plague. The second game was VERY close and we would have won on our next turn but alas the last plague cube got us yet again.

Still loving the game. Nothing really revolutionary happened with the story or play but the WAY the game plays out is very fun. Exploring and discovering new lands and how you are trying to keep cities supplied is just flat out fun to me. Still a 10/10 game.
